entry.title: The hidden meaning behind Rome's famous arch monuments
entry.summary:
Temples functioned as sites of worship, and the Colosseum served as an amphitheater for games and spectacles. But triumphal archesâ€”such as the Arch of Constantineâ€”were remarkable for being among the few purely symbolic buildings erected by the Romans. With their decorative sculptures, reliefs, and inscriptions, these monuments provide a wealth of historical sources to researchers, and their excellent state of preservation has secured them pride of place in the collective memory of many generations of scholars, travelers, and politicians interested in the ancient Roman Empire.
The triumphal arch originally grew out of the triumphal parade, a ceremony integral to life in the Roman Republic. These lavish processions through Rome were a way for generals and their soldiers to celebrate theâ€¦

entry.title: The best wineries on the Gran Canaria Wine Route
entry.summary: Gran Canaria might not be the first place you think of when it comes to wine, but vines have been growing here since the Spanish colonised the island in the 15th century. Due to the island's distinctive microclimate and volcanic soils, grapes grow incredibly well, and the Canarian archipelago lays claim to 18 unique grape varieties, including the famous MalvasÃ­a AromÃ¡tica â€” featured in some of Shakespeareâ€™s famous works. Though red varieties make up about 70% of Gran Canaria's wine production, connoisseurs should keep an eye out for local white, rosÃ©, sparkling and sweet wines, too. The best way to sample them? By taking to the trail on the Gran Canaria Wine Route â€” the only official wine route in the Canary Islands â€” which includes vineyards, bodegas, bars and restaurants that produce or â€¦

entry.title: Hoping to ski until July? Here are 7 places to go in the U.S.
entry.summary:
At Alyeska Resort in Alaska, the northern lights can sometimes be seen through April. These resorts keep the lifts spinning late into the season, providing access to some of the best springâ€”and summerâ€”skiing in North America.
It is typical to crave a tropical destination when trying to survive the last few months of winter, but skiers know that springtime is the best-kept secret in the sport.
With fewer crowds, soft snow, and long aprÃ¨s-ski afternoons spent in the sunshine, this is the best time of year to be on the mountain. The intensity of chasing mid-winter powder days has subsided, and the celebratory spring atmosphere brings a new energy.
Pack your sunscreen and warm-weather wax and get ready to enjoy the last few turns of the season. From longtime skiers to familieâ€¦

entry.title: 1 in 5 butterflies in the U.S. have disappeared
entry.summary:
Researchers compiled data on more than five hundred butterfly species across the United States from 2000 to 2020. Some species are faring better than others, but overall, butterfly numbers dropped by 22 percent.  Researchers identified over 100 species that have dropped by more than 50 percent in the last two decades: "This is a wake-up call."
In the last 20 years, one in five butterflies have disappeared in the United States.
According to a landmark study published today in the journal Science, total butterfly abundance in the U.S. has declined by 22 percent across all species between 2000 and 2020.Â
â€œThis is a wake-up call. People should be seeing this number and being very, very concerned, not just about butterflies, but about the state of insects in general,â€¦

entry.title: Darwin couldn't find these fabled horses. They've reappeared.
entry.summary:
A genetic mutation causes the Argentine Criollo horse to grow curly hair. The mysterious curly coated horses in South America evaded the famed naturalist. But now one couple is forming a herd of their ownâ€”and trying to save the species.
There, in a desolate corner of the SomuncurÃ¡ Plateau in the Argentine province of RÃ­o Negroâ€”where the word â€œinhospitableâ€ seems to have been inventedâ€”Gerardo RodrÃ­guez, a veterinarian, spotted a horse calmly grazing amid the rugged landscape. Seeing any horse in such an isolated, arid region was already unusual, but this one was unlike anything he had ever encountered: Its coat was curly.
Initially, RodrÃ­guez thought the horseâ€™s curly coat indicated it was sick or sweaty, but a gaucho, or horseman, told him something surprising: These curly-haiâ€¦

entry.title: Where to try the food on â€˜No Taste Like Home with Antoni Porowskiâ€™
entry.summary: Actress Issa Rae and No Taste Like Home host Antoni Porowski sit with Mama Yacine, Fatima Fall, Papa Abdoulaye Sene, and Hamade Ndiaye to eat ceebu jÃ«n, also known as thieboudienne, a Senegalese dish made with fish, rice, and tomato sauce. These traditional family recipes each tell a story about ancestral heritage. Here's how you can try each oneâ€”from tortellini en brodo in Italy to jajangmyeon in South Korea. InÂ National Geographicâ€™sÂ seriesÂ No Taste Like Home with Antoni Porowski, six Hollywood stars follow the Queer Eye star on a journey through food and time as they travel through their ancestral homelands in search of family history. Starting with just one homemade family recipe, Porowski helps stars Awkwafina, Justin Theroux, Issa Rae, â€¦

entry.title: Follow in Malcolm X's footsteps on a civil rights history tour in Boston
entry.summary:
West Acorn Street in Beacon Hill takes travellers along the Black Heritage Trail. Itâ€™s 100 years since the civil rights activist was born. Follow in his footsteps on a tour of Bostonâ€™s suburbs, where his legacy lives on.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Malcolm Xâ€™s birthday will be recognised as a new annual holiday in Boston this May. Though born in Nebraska in 1925, the civil rights activist lived in the Massachusetts city on and off for 12 years during a pivotal â€” if controversial â€” era in the fight for African American rights in the US. The formative years he spent in Boston â€” becoming a leading Muslim minister here before his assassination at a New York rally in 1965 â€” have left a lasting legacy that can still be seen in the cityâ€™s monumeâ€¦

entry.title: 10 of the best hotels in Salzburg, Austria
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The most Austrian of cities, Salzburg is an instant heart-stealer. Itâ€™sÂ backdropped by the MÃ¶nchsberg, a mount rising like a gentle giant above the old townâ€™s alleys and abbeys, plazas and palaces. Topping it is a 900-year-old fortress straight out of a kidsâ€™ story, while the mountains on the horizon remind you that the Alps are but a yodel away. The hotel scene mirrors the city itself: petite, characterful and surprisingly varied, skipping from revamped medieval inns to affordable palace stays. If youâ€™re visiting, book now: in 2025, Salzburg will celebrate 60 years of The Sound of Music with performances, exhibitions and tours of filming locations. Rooms in Hotel Schloss MÃ¶nchstein hold an antique and whimsical câ€¦

entry.title: Why This Colombian Investigative Reporter Had to Wait Over a Decade to Tell a Story
entry.summary: Ginna Morelo put part of her investigation into Colombian paramilitaries on hold for 13 years to protect her family and sources. She tells how she decided it was finally time to publish.

entry.title: Iâ€™m a stroke survivor. These tools make travel easier.
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*Â
I love exploring new places and enjoying adventures with family and friends. However, as a stroke survivor with autoimmune diseases as well as assorted back and leg issues, mobility considerationsâ€”sometimes accompanied by muscle aches and/or joint painâ€”are a part of my daily life. I also experience frequent vertigo that can make me lose my balance or fall. These are all factors I must consider when planning a trip.Â Â
Additionally, I help care for, â€¦

entry.title: Why March is Women's History Month in the U.S.
entry.summary:
Women have always been part of history. But for centuries, their participation in it was overlooked: Early history texts often excluded women altogether, aside from accounts of powerful women like queens. Historiansâ€”who were almost entirely menâ€”often saw the past through the lens of the â€œgreat manâ€ theory, which holds that history is largely shaped by male heroes and their struggles.
That changed in the 20th century, with the birth of womenâ€™s history as an academic discipline, a push to recognize the achievements of womenâ€”and a movement to ensure women had equal access to the academic institutions where their history might be taught. In the United States, the result was National Womenâ€™s History Month, an annual celebration born from the activism of historians intent on making sure womâ€¦

entry.title: The best way to experience Alpine culture? Eatâ€”and drinkâ€”it
entry.summary:
Harsh temperatures and unpredictable high-altitude soil have strengthened the roots of the Alps, and the farmers living there are as resilient as the food they grow. Here, people have survived the unimaginable: In 1916, more than 200 Austro-Hungarian World War I soldiers lived at 12,000 feet for a year inside Italyâ€™s Marmolada Glacier, in a city of ice tunnels they dug by hand, rationing bread and meat, and, when they could get it, a soft sweet bundt cake called gugelhupf to ease their pain.
Those hidden ice trenches are now the site of another slow battle: Climate change is expected to melt the glacier completely by 2040.
Through thick and thin â€” traversing dangerous mountain passes in winter storms, avalanches, and in the face of climate change â€” lives in the Alps have dependedâ€¦

entry.title: 10 lizards came to Cincinnati in a sock. Now there are thousands.
entry.summary:
A Lazarus lizard suns itself on a warm rock in Burnet Woods, one of many European transplants that have taken over Cincinnati, Ohio. Scientists say the cityâ€™s hills, aging infrastructure, and even its climate have helped them thrive. Native to Europe, common wall lizards are growing bigger, faster, and more resilient in Ohio. Scientists say the city itself may be driving their evolution.
For more than 70 years, thousands of common wall lizards, known as Lazarus lizards, from Europe have made Cincinnati their home. Even through record-low temperatures and snowfall, theyâ€™ve managed to surviveâ€”and multiply. But how did these Mediterranean reptiles gain such a foothold in a Midwestern city? It all started with a 10-year-old boy and a sock full of lizards.
In 1951, George Rau Jr., â€¦

entry.title: What are menopause retreats and how do they help?
entry.summary:
The Preidlhof Garden Spa offers nature-inspired treatments. The transformative journey of menopause is finally stepping into the spotlight, with specialised retreats offering tailored support to nurture both body and mind during this pivotal phase.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Menopause and perimenopause were once topics shrouded in silence, leaving women to navigate the physical and emotional challenges alone. Today, thanks to trailblazers like Davina McCall, awareness has surged, with women openly sharing their experiences, healthcare professionals taking a more proactive approach and workplaces offering menopause training. This shift marks a new era of support and understanding for women during this crucial life stage, and has led to thâ€¦

entry.title: Scientists find a new titanosaur dinosaur species in Patagonia
entry.summary:
Hundreds of fossils found at a quarry in Northern Patagonia provide a snapshot of what a desert pond ecosystem might have looked like in the late Cretaceous period. Researchers found a previously undiscovered species of titanosaur (illustrated above) among other fossilized creatures at the site.  The new Argentine dino might give us clues to what the world was like before the asteroid wiped out their kind.
In Northern Patagonia, paleontologists have unearthed an ancient lagoon ecosystem surrounded by sand dunes and palm trees where prehistoric creatures thrived. Excavations of 78 million year-old rocks, from a quarry just outside General Roca city in Argentina, yielded a treasure trove of 432 fossils belonging to over a hundred animal groups.
The majority of theâ€¦

entry.title: Meet the Maya artisans of Lake AtitlÃ¡n
entry.summary:
One of many myths surrounding Lake AtitlÃ¡n tells of an ancient Maya sorceress who forged a magic ring for a Spanish conquistador, swearing it would make him irresistible to the object of his affection. Long story short: the plan went sideways, and the ring was lost at the bottom of the lake. There it remains, they say, still casting its spell through the water like an electric current, drawing travellers to these shores and compelling them to fall in love with the place.
It worked on the hippies, who drifted this way in the 1960s, when word spread of a spectacular lake with mystical powers in west-central Guatemala. It works on contemporary wellness enthusiasts, who now sustain an industry of yoga retreats, thermal spas and â€˜psychic developmentâ€™ courses. And it works on me, too â€” thouâ€¦

entry.title: A New Digital Archive to Preserve an Investigative Legacy in Central America
entry.summary: The Central American Independent Media Archive (CAIMA) seeks to preserve reporting from threatened or shuttered accountability media sites across the region.

entry.title: Does slurping or loud chewing enrage you? You may have misophonia.
entry.summary:
For those with misophonia, everyday sounds like slurping or chewing can trigger a fight-or-flight response. Scientists are working to understand why. For people with misophonia, the sound of chewing, tapping, or sniffing isnâ€™t just annoyingâ€”itâ€™s unbearable. Scientists are unraveling the mystery behind this little-known condition and how to treat it.
Everyone gets annoyed by certain noises at times. You might wince at the screech of feedback from a microphone or want to scream at the construction worker pummeling a pneumatic drill outside your window. But for some people, the quietest sounds are the most excruciating.
For people with misophonia, every day sounds like slurping, tapping, or sniffing donâ€™t just annoyâ€”they trigger an intense fight-or-flight response. The condition,â€¦

entry.title: The secret to a healthy gut is simpler than you think
entry.summary:
One of the secrets to better gut health is simpler than you might think: Eating a wide variety of plants helps a wide variety of beneficial bacteria flourish in your gut microbiome, according to a large study published in the journal Nature Microbiology. And itâ€™s still good for you even if you occasionally enjoy meat, which is otherwiseÂ linked to more â€œbadâ€ bacteria.
For the study, more than 21,000 people in the United States, United Kingdom, and Italy used an app to answer detailed questionnaires about what they ate on a regular basis. Their diets were grouped into three buckets: omnivore (including meat, dairy, and plants), vegetarian (no meat), or vegan (no animal products).
The researchers used DNA technology to analyze participantsâ€™ stool samples, which allowed them to identâ€¦

entry.title: The internetâ€™s favorite bald eagles just had hatchlings
entry.summary:
Shadow the bald eagle stands guard over three eggs in his nest atop a 145-foot tree in Big Bear Lake Forest in California. Shadow and his mate Jackie have become internet sensations thanks to a nest cam that documents their daily lives. After losing their chicks for the past two years, these famous bird parents finally got some good news at long last.
Jackie and Shadow, a beloved bald eagle pair in Big Bear Lake Forest, a hundred miles northeast of Los Angeles, welcomed two new chicks into the world, one at around 4 a.m. on March 4 and the other at 11:36 p.m. on March 3. The world is still waiting to see if another eaglet emerges from the coupleâ€™s third egg.
"So, all of us are just crying tears of joy for eagle babies in the middle of the night?" commented one Facebook user onâ€¦

entry.title: Scientists may finally know why starlings form mesmerizing clouds
entry.summary:
A convergence of starlings swirls above St. Peterâ€™s Basilica in Rome. For centuries, researchers have pondered how starlings travel in those gorgeous shape-shifting clouds. The answers continue to surprise them.
On winter eveningsÂ throughout much of Europe and North America, an hour before sunset, thousands of starlings gather in the skies. Before descending to their nighttime roosts, the birds put on one of natureâ€™s most spectacular displays. They pulse, ripple, and wheel as if they were a single entityâ€”an amorphous, shape-shifting creature with the delicate beauty of calligraphic brushstrokes and the erratic chaos of flickering flames.
How could so many birds be so tightly coordinated? Thatâ€™s a mystery that researchers have sought to solve for more than a century. In 1931, tâ€¦

entry.title: How to plan the ultimate adventure through Southern Mexico
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
A region of small-hold farms and understated towns, Mexicoâ€™s southern states remain truest to the countryâ€™s Indigenous roots. There are settlements here that have endured for more than 5,000 years. Those who visit the vast valleys of Oaxaca and the jungles of Chiapas today can glimpse authentic insights into the day-to-day lives of their first peoples.
Both Oaxaca and Chiapas were distinct centres of civilisation long before the Aztec Empire arose in central Mexico around 1300 CE. Each sustained its own grand, hidden city â€” Oaxacaâ€™s mountaintop Monte AlbÃ¡n flourished from 500 BCE to 850 CE, while Chiapasâ€™s forest-shrouded Palenque was at its height in the sixth and seventh centuries CE.
The influence of each â€¦

entry.title: 6 of the best places to eat and drink in Lyon
entry.summary:
From Michelin-starred restaurants to cosy bistros, discover Lyon's superb gastronomy by eating your way around the city.
Positioned at the crossroads of Burgundy and the Rhone Valley, Lyon has long occupied a position of culinary privilege. Its chefs are spoiled by superior produce drawn from the local area, including wines from the vineyards of Beaujolais and cheeses and meats from the foothills of the Alps. In the city, restaurant offerings range from high-level classic French cuisine to international fusion concepts brought here by creative chefs from around the world. Whatever you fancy eating, youâ€™ll find it in Lyon â€” just be sure to bring a big appetite.
The narrow streets of Vieux Lyon are a maze of Renaissance buildings, secret passageways and beautiful courtyards. â€¦

entry.title: Flying in 2025? Hereâ€™s how to find the cheapest flights
entry.summary:
Flight alerts help travelers track fluctuating prices, so you know when your ideal flight drops in cost. From myth-busting outdated tips to the best search tools, travel experts weigh in on how to find affordable airfare.
Booking affordable airfare can be a turbulent process. Prices rise and fall day by day, or in some cases, hour by hour. In the past, frequent fliers swore by loose strategies to find deals â€” book on a Tuesday! No, on a Wednesday! Never on a weekend! â€” but experts caution that many suggestions donâ€™t amount to more than myth.
While finding cheap airfare might feel futile, itâ€™s not impossible. Hereâ€™s what experts say you need to know.
If you're looking for a cross-country flight this summer, you'll notice that the prices tend to go up and down. One day, iâ€¦

entry.title: What we know about the mysterious illness in the DRC
entry.summary:
Colored transmission electron micrograph (TEM) of a human red blood cell (red) infected with the malarial parasite Plasmodium sp. (blue). Malaria is one of several suspected culprits of this outbreak, as it was revealed as the cause of another mystery disease outbreak in the DRC at the end of 2024. The unidentified ailment has sickened 1,300 people and led to more than 50 deaths. Regardless of the cause, experts say containing the outbreak will be challenging.
  Over the past month, an unidentified illness has sickened more than 1,300 people and led to more than 50 deaths in the northwestern part of the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). The exact cause of the outbreak is still unknown, although the World Health Organization hypothesizes it could be some combinâ€¦

entry.title: Gaza: Deep concern for civilians as aid crossings remain shut

entry.title: Almost 80,000 flee DR Congo amid fighting, sexual violence: UNHCR

entry.title: The lost homes of enslaved Africans may be hidden in their bones
entry.summary:
Strontium is an alkaline earth metal that is soft, silvery-white and turns yellow when exposed to airâ€”it's often used in fireworks for this reason. It also shows up in bedrock, so researchers are using the element to help trace the roots of ancestors forcibly displaced by the transatlantic slave trade. Scientists have created a groundbreaking map of strontium isotopes found across sub-Saharan Africaâ€”which could help descendants of enslaved people reconstruct their family histories.
â€œWhere were my ancestors?â€ is a question thatâ€™s followed Andre Kearns for as long as he can remember. He still recalls his middle school geography assignment to color in a map of New York City with the different ethnic enclaves at the turn of the 20th century. When Kearns began to shade in a Black neighbâ€¦

Spring weather can be downright confusingâ€”one minute itâ€™s raining, then itâ€™s freezing, then itâ€™s sunny and warm. Needless to say, the seasonâ€™s unpredictability can make it difficult to figure out what to pack.Â
Whether youâ€™re traveling or updating your wardrobe, the best spring jacket should be a multitasker.Â Â
â€œWhen searching for a specific item to add to your wardrobe, I remind my clients to think of two things in tandem: functionality and fâ€¦

entry.title: Bone pit hints at human, animal sacrifice in Roman-era Britain
entry.summary:
Dead puppies, potential human sacrifices and a painted dog penis bone buried in a ritual deposit in an ancient quarry shaft in southern England are revealing what fertility rituals may have looked like in the early decades of Roman conquest.
â€œIt was filled with an absolutely shocking number of bones,â€ says Ellen Green, a bioarchaeologist at the University of Reading. â€œYou couldnâ€™t move around in there without stepping on something.â€ Green describes the find in a recent issue of the Oxford Journal of Archaeology.Â
The hole full of bonesâ€”the largest ritual deposit discovered of its kind dating to the Roman Britain periodâ€”gives archaeologists hints about the ways that conquered British didâ€”and didnâ€™tâ€”adopt the cultural practices of Rome as early as the first century A.D.
Greeâ€¦

entry.title: How to experience Carnival in the Caribbean
entry.summary:
In Barbados, Grand Kadooment Day is traditionally held on the first Monday in August every year to mark the end of the six-week celebration, Crop Over, and the end of the sugarcane harvest. More than just a party, Carnival is a tradition steeped in history. We delve into unique celebrations across the islands, from stickfighting and chipping in Trinidad to Junkanoo in the Bahamas.
More than two dozen countries make up the Caribbean, each with its own vernacular, history, food, and culture. Despite these distinctions, one tradition connects every islandâ€”Carnival. Born from the ingenuity of enslaved African people determined to survive in the face of brutality, the tradition has survived over the years with much of the same song, dance, and even mockery that were integral parts of iâ€¦

entry.title: Can guys and girls really just be friends? Ask these baboons.
entry.summary:
A young Kinda baboon at Mahale Mountains Nationalpark, Tansania. A new study found this species of baboon forms long term male and female friendships. These friendships often lasted for life, and scientists say they show how male primates can use kindness and affection to socially succeed.
Observing the same group of wild baboons for over a decade, primatologist Anna Weyher says their individual personalities begin to stand out. One baboon named Simon was a good father, a â€œnice guyâ€ to female baboons, while his brother Garfunkel was â€œmore grumpy.â€Â
â€œOver time you get to know them so well,â€ says Weyher.Â Â
After observing Kinda baboons (Papio kindae) in Zambiaâ€™s Kasanka National Park for nine years, Weyherâ€™s research team published their findings in January, the first longâ€¦

entry.title: A neighbourhood guide to Copenhagen
entry.summary:
Copenhagen may be a compact city â€”Â you can cycle from one side to the other in about 15 minutes â€”Â but itâ€™s built upon a vibrant patchwork of distinct, characterful neighbourhoods. Depending on where you stay, you may find yourself surrounded by innovative new builds, trendy brewpubs or contemporary art spaces, each one offering a different way of experiencing the city. Here, we take a look at some of the city's most intriguing neighbourhoods â€” from Christianshavn's historic, colourful streets to the inventive modern architecture of Nordhavn. Take some time to explore and decide which is the one for you.
For independent shops and cafes Known for being the cityâ€™s former red-light district, Vesterbro has cleaned up its act and is now full of independent shops, vintage boutiques and casâ€¦

entry.title: Why northern Portugal should be your next road trip destination
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Of all the seasons in Portugal, summer is the longest and most beloved, with warm days crowned by burnished sunsets reaching well into the harvest months. In the busy cities and beach towns of the countryâ€™s south, it can be easy to deny the subtle shifts in the landscape that signal the tiptoe into autumn. But in the countryâ€™s untamed north, the scenery demands to be read: amber grapes swell on trellised vines, chestnut groves pound the earth with their fruit and fat mushrooms bloom in forests simmering with golden leaves. The signs are unmistakable on my drive from Porto to the hamlet of Amares, in the depths of the Minho region.
Yet perhaps I still have summer on my mind as I launch myself from a meadow bank intoâ€¦

entry.title: These are the best swimsuits for women in 2025
entry.summary:

For many women, shopping for the perfect swimsuit can feel like searching for a unicorn. Will it look good on and stay on? Will I have to constantly adjust it while Iâ€™m swimming, snorkeling or even walking on the beach?Â Â
To help, we asked active women who spend lots of time in a swimsuit to share their top picks and tips. They may spend more time in bathing suits than most, but their concerns are similar to that of most women. We all want to look â€¦

entry.title: See how the spice trade legacy continues to shape Kochi, India
entry.summary:
Kochi's inhabitants carry great pride in their spice-infused history. Gateway to the canals and lagoons of the Kerala backwaters and to the Arabian Sea, Kochi was for centuries a major hub for the spice trade. This legacy has left an indelible mark on its identity and continues to shape the multilayered city today.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK). undefined undefined The backwaters can be just as colourful, with garlands of marigolds hung over the sides of boats. Representing the sun and symbolising brightness and auspiciousness, marigolds are often used during celebrations and as offerings throughout India. Keralaâ€™s backwaters run parallel to the Arabian Sea, stretching north and south of Kochi. Theyâ€™re home to plantations growing a variety of spices such as cloves, nutmeg, cardamom, cinnamon and turmeric. Fruits including bananas, coconuts and mangoes also thrive here. Life on the plantations is dictated by the rhythms of nature and the changing seasons. Published in the March 2025 issue of National Geographic Traveller (UK). To subscribe toÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK) magazine click here. (Available in select countries only).

entry.title: 15 of the best UK destinations for spring travel
entry.summary:
Tintern Abbey is a 13th-century gothic masterpiece sitting beside the River Wye in southeast Wales. From the Yorkshire moors to the Cornish seaside, these alluring spots make for a classic British holiday.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Whether youâ€™re longing to fill your lungs with sea air or are looking to spend some quiet days rambling through the countryside, these UK destinations are all perfectly suited to spring travel. From the â€˜Queen of Welsh resortsâ€™ to the region thatâ€™s home to the UKâ€™s rarest butterfly species, these are 15 of the best destinations to escape to this Easter holiday and beyond.
The West Midlands county of Staffordshire was once a powerhouse of innovation, taking 18th-centuryÂ BritainÂ into a ground-breaking fuâ€¦

entry.title: Rediscover real island living
entry.summary:
White sand, blush-pink granite boulders, and verdant coastal forest define the inner islands of Seychelles. Untouched until the 18th century, Seychelles is a remarkable place of pristine natural beauty. This nation of granitic and coralline isles scattered in the Indian Ocean redefines the idea of an island escape.
There are many places that call themselves paradise, but Seychelles, near-equatorial islands strung like emeralds through the turquoise blues of the remote western Indian Ocean, surely claims the crown. A hotbed of biodiversity, these coral-fringed, jungle-clad isles were spotted by the Portuguese explorer Vasco da Gama in 1502, but the first Europeans to set foot here were Britishâ€”representatives of the British East India Company in 1609. Yet Seychelles remained unsettlâ€¦

entry.title: Why there's never been a better time to travel with your pets
entry.summary:
Many hotels across the globe, such as The Hoxton in Southwark, London, now cater for travellers with pets. More people are travelling with their animal than ever. Hereâ€™s what you need to know from how to fly with your dog to the latest pet-focused services.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
New statistics have highlighted the rising demand for pet-friendly travel experiences. The 2024 Annual Vacation Confidence Index by Allianz Partners USA found that over 40% of US travellers aged 34-54 years old will include their pets on their next holiday, with 24% of those over 55 doing the same.
Several travel companies in the UK have reported a rise in pet-friendly bookings over the past couple of years. Dog-friendly accommodation site Paws & Stay â€¦

entry.title: Americaâ€™s original vacation hotspot is making a comeback
entry.summary:
Lake Placid and Whiteface Mountain is a famous sight of the Adirondacks. The American vacation was born in the Adirondack Mountains â€” and now this remote region is experiencing a revival.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Rowing cross-handed takes some getting used to, but thatâ€™s the technique required to master an Adirondack guide boat â€” the lightweight yet sturdy wooden vessel built for the rugged waterways of northern New York State. After a knuckle-bashing start with its long oars, Iâ€™m soon gliding across the glassy surface of Sagamore Lake. â€œYouâ€™re rewiring your brain right now,â€ says my guide, Cari Ray. â€œDoesnâ€™t that feel good?â€
The plaintive calls of a solitary loon echo across the water, but aside from this bird weâ€™re alone on thâ€¦

entry.title: The harrowing history behind 'I'm Still Here'
entry.summary:
On a hot January morning in 1971, plainclothes security agents knocked on the door of the beachfront home of former Brazilian lawmaker Rubens Paiva. Hustled into his car, Paiva was sped away under armed escort and never seen again, leaving his wife and five children to pick up the pieces. This is the broad plotline of Iâ€™m Still Here, the Oscar-winning film set during Brazilian military rule. But rather than dwell on the dictatorsâ€™ dungeons and the all too visceral horrors of state-sponsored violence, director Walter Salles flips the narrative.
Instead, the film pivots to Paivaâ€™s wife, then widow, Eunice, as she relentlessly presses an obtuse military junta for justice over the next five decades, even as she struggles to provide for a fractured family. Itâ€™s an intimate window on Brazilâ€¦

entry.title: 7 luxurious hotels you can feel good about checking into
entry.summary:
Populas in Denver, Colorado, is a carbon-positive hotel, meaning that it aims to reduce more carbon than it creates. From a new purpose-driven safari in South Africa to a carbon-positive hotel in the United States, hereâ€™s how to turn your next stay into a force for good.
Travel trends come and go, but when it comes to sustainability, these hotels are all in.
â€œBy choosing accommodation providers with strong sustainability practices, such as those supporting local conservation efforts or engaging in community initiatives, travelers can ensure their stays align with their personal values while positively impacting the environment and the communities they visit,â€ says Sally Davey, CEO of sustainable travel organization Travalyst.
Davey, who also works in collaboration with thâ€¦

entry.title: Deadly wildfires are making their way east
entry.summary:
Two men spray water on a raging fire as it threatens homes in Conway, South Carolina. Wildfires may be more common in the West but could deadlier in the East where they're more likely to burn through homes and businesses.  We all know wildfires have been getting worse in the drought-stricken western U.S., but experts say the growing risk on the east coast is concerning.
When we think of wildfires, we often think of western states like California where massive blazes, such as the fires that burned in and around Los Angeles earlier this year. But more than 100 fires recently burned through North and South Carolina amid dry and windy conditions.
While California and other western states face a high wildfire risk, the west is less densely populated and fires often arise in tâ€¦

Whether youâ€™re facing sudden showers or chilly breezes while traveling in the spring, a reliable, lightweight jacket is an essential part of any packing list.Â
â€œLook for something you can wear year-round,â€ says Justin Shachter, a NASA engineer and an outdoor enthusiast based in Los Angeles, California. â€œYouâ€™ll want to be protected during a 70-degree day, yet warm enough if it gets down to 45 or 50.â€Â
â€œIâ€™m looking for something water resistant.â€¦

entry.title: The meaning of the cross of ashes on Ash Wednesday
entry.summary:
A woman with a cross of ashes on her forehead attends a traditional Ash Wednesday service at the Metropolitan Cathedral in San Jose, Costa Rica. The Christian holiday marks the start of Lent, a 40-day period of penance that culminates on Easter. The holiday marks the start of a period of reflection and repentance that lasts until Easter.
Wondering why a small dusty cross anoints the foreheads of Christians once a year? They're celebrating Ash Wednesday, which for many also marks the start of Lent, a 40-day period of penance and reflection leading up to Easter. Here's what you need to know about a holiday marked by ash crosses and fasting.
Ash Wednesday always falls on the Wednesday six and a half weeks before Easter, which Christians around the world believe is the day that â€¦

entry.summary: At night he sleeps under a tarpaulin sheet on the ruins of his family home. Like others returning to northern Gaza after months of being displaced by war, Sufian Al-Majdalawi clings to whatever he can find.

entry.summary: Bahrain, with its shallow waters and rich oyster beds, has long been synonymous with pearls, which formed the backbone of the island nationâ€™s economy for thousands of years. Diving for pearls, otherwise known as pearling, remains part of the countryâ€™s cultural DNA.

Pairwise model evaluation means comparing two models directly against each other to assess their relative performance on a specific task. The Gen AI evaluation service in Vertex AI lets you evaluate any generative model or application and benchmark the evaluation results against your own judgmentï¼Œ using your own evaluation criteria. LLM Comparator's interface is highly intuitive for side-by-side comparisons of different model outputsï¼Œ making it an excellent tool to augment automated LLM evaluation with human-in-the-loop processes. ğŸ“Š æ–‡ç« ä¿¡æ¯

entry.title: Haiti: Over one million displaced by gang violence
entry.summary: Ongoing gang violence in Haiti has displaced more than a million people, nearly a tenth of the population, or three times more than last year, the UN Humanitarian Coordinator in the country said on Thursday.

entry.title: This is the worst flu season in 15 years. Here's why.
entry.summary:
Seasonal flu cases have hitÂ a 15-year high this yearâ€”filling hospitals,Â shutting down schools, andÂ leading to an estimated 19,000 flu-related deathsÂ so far in theÂ United States. These deaths even topped winter COVID-19-related deathsÂ for the first time since the pandemic began five years ago.
While flu cases surge, RSV, norovirus, and COVID-19 infections have also remained high, "putting a significant strain on hospitalsâ€”particularly as patients compete for the same resources such as intensive care unit beds and healthcare personnel," says Jason Nagata, a pediatrician at University of California, San Francisco Benioff Childrenâ€™s Hospital. "Hospitals are struggling to keep up with the demand, and some have been forced to set up temporary triage tents."
Moreover, this flu seasonÂ moâ€¦

entry.title: How drugs like Wegovy might affect kids in the long term
entry.summary:
Fifteen-year-old Jenny Arrellin has struggled for years to lose weight through diet and exercise because of her polycystic ovary syndromeÂ (PCOS), a complex hormonal and metabolic disorder thatâ€™s associated with excess weight and insulin resistance. Knowing she was at risk of developing type 2 diabetes,Â in March 2024 she decided to participate in a study of Wegovy, a GLP-1 receptor agonist drug similar to Ozempic.
The drug curbed her appetite considerably and changed her taste in foodsâ€”â€œI stopped liking pizza and chips and now I donâ€™t like candy at all,â€ she says. It also eliminated the food noise she used to get when she was bored.Â But "the biggest change is I don't eat nearly as much as I used to," she adds.
(Canâ€™t stop thinking about your next meal? Thatâ€™s "food noise.")
Nâ€¦

entry.title: How Lake Erie became a devastating snow machine
entry.summary:
Ashtabula, OhioJim Timonere has been watching and waiting for Lake Erie to freeze over, just to catch a break.
Itâ€™s been a brutal winter for communities along the southeastern and eastern shores of Lake Erie that spans Ohio, Pennsylvania, and New York.
Last Thanksgiving Day weekend, the region was paralyzed by a â€œhistoricâ€ storm that saw almost six feet of snow upend life across hundreds of miles.
â€œWhen I woke up at 3 a.m. to check the snowfall I thought: â€˜no big deal,â€™â€ he recalls.Â
â€œTwo hours later, I looked outside, and it was: â€˜Oh, my god.â€™ We got feet of snow in a matter of hours.â€
Roofs of more than a dozen structures in Ashtabula collapsed, including the local high schoolâ€™s, forcing hundreds of students to take online classes for a month.Â
â€œWeâ€™re used tâ€¦

entry.title: If you must work on vacation, try packing a portable monitor
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*Â
While no one should have to work on vacation, sometimes itâ€™s unavoidable. Working on the road poses its own set of trials and tribulations, but one major complaint is the lack of monitor real estate. For some, a portable monitor may be the solution. Not only do they expand your workspace, they offer some physiological benefits tooâ€”an important consideration when youâ€™re traveling in unfamiliar places.Â

entry.title: Is this Portugalâ€™s ultimate spot for stargazing?
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Deep in Portugalâ€™s rural south, the region of Alentejo is dry and sun-scorched. Low hills of parched grassland roll towards the horizon, eucalyptus plants glint silver in the sun, and thousand-year-old olive trees stand sentinel over the landscape. Today, however, another colour dominates: a vast expanse of cerulean blue. This is the Alqueva Reservoir, Western Europeâ€™s largest artificial body of water, formed in 2002. When night falls, shooting stars seem to bounce off the water and myriad constellations reflect off its glassy surface. Designated the worldâ€™s first Starlight Tourism Destination, with few towns and miles of uninterrupted countryside, the region may brim with daytime adventures, but itâ€™s at night that Alenâ€¦

entry.title: How to plan an epic road trip from El Paso, Texas
entry.summary:
There are many extraordinary US road trips, but one of the most notable is traversing the breathtaking Southwest. Bordering Mexico and the state of New Mexico, the sun-drenched Texan city of El Paso is the ideal gateway to the sights, culture and flavours of this diverse region. Since the 16th century, El Paso has evolved from a Spanish settlement to a frontier town to a thriving border city. It now reflects a rich fusion of Spanish, Mexican and American influences, which include centuries-old missions, lively mariachi music and artisanal cowboy bootmakers. Sitting alongside the Rio Grande, El Pasoâ€™s proximity to several state and national parks makes the city a great base for an adventure-packed week-long road trip.
Start the day with a scenic drive up Transmountain Road and waâ€¦

entry.title: For a new perspective on Chicago's architecture, head indoors
entry.summary:
Boat tours down the Chicago River is the most popular â€” but not the only â€” way to see the city's architecture. New insider tours are offering a glimpse into the usually off-limits interiors of some of the cityâ€™s most celebrated buildings.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
If urban legend is to be believed, the world was forever changed on a dry, windy Chicago evening on 8 October 1871 by a cow called Daisy. She knocked over a lantern, causing one of the largest urban fires in modern history. Around 3.5sq miles of the Illinois city burned down, destroying more than 17,000 buildings and leaving a blank canvas for new architectural styles and groundbreaking engineering.
The rebuild began almost instantly and, by 1885, Chicago had enshrined iâ€¦

entry.title: Afraid of flying? Here are 7 tricks to manage your anxiety.
entry.summary:
Travelers typically welcome the jolt of excited adrenaline that sharpens the senses and takes our breath temporarily awayâ€”itâ€™s the physical proof of an awe-inspiring adventure. Yet, those same reactions, far less pleasant in the form of anxiety, are also an inevitable part of travel, the other side of noveltyâ€™s biochemical coin.Â Â
For an increasing number of travelers, that anxiety is centered around flying. While air travel remains one of theÂ safest modes of transportation, an estimatedÂ 25 million adults in the United States experienced a degree of aerophobiaÂ as of 2022. In the wake of tragic crashes in the first months of 2025, online searches for "fear of flying" and "flight anxiety" exponentially increased.Â
Yet travel demand remains up, with more thanÂ 5 billion airline passeâ€¦

entry.title: What Black history has to do with the Cretaceous period
entry.summary:
As a public historian and National Geographic Explorer,Â Iâ€™m constantly on the trail of interesting stories that connect a series of events dating back several centuries but continue to resonate into modern times. On a recent road trip through the American South, my partner, National Geographic photographer Kris Graves, and I drove through Tuskegee, Alabama, where we found a connection to a time long before human beings walked the Earth.
Itâ€™s a story of how the geology of the Cretaceous Period, between 70 and 100 Million years ago, emphatically changed the course of American history.
About 80 miles from Tuskegee, along highway 431, we approached Horseshoe Bend National Military Park. Not to be confused the "Horseshoe Bend" segment of the Colorado River in Arizona, this site, estâ€¦

entry.summary: Shuttered clinics and health workers laid off around the world reflect the widespread, negative toll the United States funding freeze is taking on the global AIDS response, according to a new situation report released on Wednesday by the UN agency charged with responding to the disease.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Syria: UN scales up aid deliveries as regional fighting continues
entry.summary: UN humanitarians on Wednesday reported a scaling up of humanitarian aid into northwest Syria, even as hostilities continue to impact civilians and limit access in different parts of the country.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Human Rights Council: Gaza ceasefire must hold, TÃ¼rk insists
entry.summary: UN human rights chiefÂ Volker TÃ¼rk issued aÂ strong appeal on Wednesday for the fragile ceasefire in Gaza to hold, amid delays to talks between Hamas and Israel on extending the truce into the second phase.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sudan war: Any peace deal must respect national sovereignty, UN envoy says
entry.summary: As the war in Sudan approaches a second year, the UN Secretary-Generalâ€™s Personal Envoy for the country has emphasized the need to re-double and coordinate efforts towards a peace agreement that respects national sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity â€“ and end the worldâ€™s largest humanitarian crisis.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Conflict has turned parts of Sudan â€˜into a hellscape,â€™ Security Council hears
entry.summary: A senior UN aid official has called on the Security Council to ensure better protection for civilians in Sudan together with unhindered humanitarian access, as the brutal war between rival militaries approaches a second year.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Greatest threat to UN Peacekeeping is divisions between nations, says UN Peace Operations Chief
entry.summary: Peacekeeping efforts by the United Nations are being challenged by growing disunity between Member States, the UN head of Peace Operations, Jean-Pierre Lacroix said in an interview with UN News, during the Conference for Women Peacekeepers in New Delhi.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Somalia faces escalating crisis amid drought, conflict and price hikes
entry.summary: The humanitarian situation in Somalia is worsening as drought, conflict and soaring food prices push millions toward extreme hunger, UN agencies warned on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: West Bank security situation remains alarming, warn UN aid agencies
entry.summary: Weeks of deadly Israeli military raids in the occupied West Bank have turned Palestinian communities into â€œbattlefieldsâ€ and left 40,000 people homeless, UN humanitarians warned on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Appendix A: Comparing results across Religious Landscape Studies
entry.summary: Many questions in the 2023-24 Religious Landscape Study (RLS) previously were asked in the 2007 and 2014 landscape studies. Measuring change over time on these questions is one key goal of the new RLS. But the 2023-24 survey was conducted using different methods from the 2007 and 2014 surveys, and this â€œmode switchâ€ complicates comparisons [â€¦] The post Appendix A: Comparing results across Religious Landscape Studies appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 9. Race and ethnicity in religious congregations
entry.summary: Americans who go to religious services tend to worship at places where most other congregants and senior leaders share their race or ethnicity. Religious Landscape Study by Pew Research Center. The post 9. Race and ethnicity in religious congregations appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 8. Religious attendance and congregational involvement
entry.summary: A third of adults attend in-person services at least monthly, while 23% virtually watch that often. And 37% are members of a house of worship. Religious Landscape Study by Pew Research Center. The post 8. Religious attendance and congregational involvement appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 6. Religion, fertility and child-rearing
entry.summary: Read about how adultsâ€™ average number of kids vary by religious group, and how many parents pray with their kids, opt for a religious education and more. Religious Landscape Study by Pew Research Center. The post 6. Religion, fertility and child-rearing appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 7. Importance of religion and the Bible
entry.summary: About four-in-ten U.S. adults say religion is very important. Most Christians see the Bible as important to them. Religious Landscape Study by Pew Research Center. The post 7. Importance of religion and the Bible appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 5. Religious upbringing and childhood education
entry.summary: As a kid, most Americans say they were raised in a religion, went to religious services at least monthly, and had at least some religious education. Religious Landscape Study by Pew Research Center. The post 5. Religious upbringing and childhood education appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 4. Religious intermarriage
entry.summary: Most who are married say their spouse shares their religion, while 26% donâ€™t. Read about interreligious marriages, spouses discussing religion and more. Religious Landscape Study by Pew Research Center. The post 4. Religious intermarriage appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. Identifying with a religion because of culture, ethnicity or family background
entry.summary: Identifying with a group for reasons â€œaside from religionâ€ â€“ such as ethnically, culturally, or because of family background â€“ is somewhat rare. Religious Landscape Study by Pew Research Center. The post 3. Identifying with a religion because of culture, ethnicity or family background appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Religious switching
entry.summary: Millions of Americans have switched religions over the course of their lives, and most say their religiousness or spirituality has generally shifted too. Religious Landscape Study by Pew Research Center. The post 2. Religious switching appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. Religious identity
entry.summary: Christiansâ€™ share among U.S. adults has fallen across demographic groups since 2007, but there has been overall stability in religious makeup since 2020. Religious Landscape Study by Pew Research Center. The post 1. Religious identity appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Carlo Rovelli: the physics and philosophy of time
entry.summary: What is the meaning of â€˜nowâ€™? An Italian physicist takes us on a journey to the edges of our understanding of time - by Aeon Video Watch at Aeon

entry.title: Why Ramadan is the most sacred month in Islamic culture
entry.summary:
During the holy month of Ramadan, Muslims build stronger relationships with Allah through fasting, selfless actions, and prayingâ€”like this Palestinian man praying at the Great Mosque of Gaza. The mosque, once the largest and oldest in the Gaza Strip, was destroyed by an airstrike in December 2023.

The sighting of a new crescent moon marks the start of Ramadan, a time for piety and self-reflection. Every year, Muslims around the world anticipate the sighting of the new crescent moon that signifies the official first day of Ramadan, the ninth month of the Islamic calendar and the most sacred month in Islamic culture. The start of Ramadan fluctuates each year because the lunar Islamic calendar follows the phases of the moon. It begins the day after the new crescent moon, wâ€¦

entry.title: 13 of the best books to inspire your next trip
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*
Guidebooks can be wonderful resources for helping travelers navigate destinations. But the best travel books can also inspire journeys. Fiction or nonfiction, thereâ€™s no shortage of books with a sense of place just waiting to spark your next adventure.Â
As a travel journalist and lifelong book lover, I often look to books for trip ideas. When I find a new title I love, I add it to my packing list. Doing so doesnâ€™t just encourage planning; it enhanceâ€¦

entry.title: How a new pope is elected
entry.summary:
After Pope Benedict XVIâ€™s resignation in 2013, it took two long weeks for the Catholic faithful to receive an answerâ€”who would be their next representative of God on Earth?
Crowds in Saint Peter's Square at the Vatican let out a cheer as the white smoke from burned ballots signified a successful vote among the members of the College of Cardinals.Â It was the final act that sealed the intricate papal selection process that allegedly dates back to the time of Jesus Christ.
The drama of this sacred and mysterious ritual is depicted in the Academy Award-nominated filmÂ Conclave,Â which tells the story of what happens after the death of a fictional pope. But how much of its portrayal is true to history? Hereâ€™s a closer look at the real story behind one of the Vaticanâ€™s most mysterious aâ€¦

entry.title: Hereâ€™s your essential safari packing list
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*Â
For many travelers, going on a safari is a lifelong dream. I recently lived that dream on a 14-day Namibia expedition with Wilderness Travel, where we tracked leopards and marveled at wildlife congregating at watering holes, hiked the ochre-hued Sossusvlei Dunes, and camped on â€œdune bedsâ€ under a blanket of stars. I did it all with just a duffel bag and a backpack.Â Â
African safaris can include game drives, walking safaris, and other activities. Moâ€¦

entry.title: Newfound 'Valley of the Kings' tomb is the first in 100 years
entry.summary:
For the first time in years, archaeologists have stepped inside the tomb of an ancient Egyptian pharaohâ€”to be greeted by hallmark hieroglyphs on the walls and traces of a faded celestial mural on the ceiling painted thousands of years ago.
Last week, Egyptâ€™s Ministry of Tourism and Antiquities announced that a joint British and Egyptian archaeological team had uncovered the new find, which could change modern understandings of the ancientÂ kingdom at a critical time in the 15th century B.C. It also highlights how Egyptology has changed from its origins in the 19th and early 20th centuries, when the western word was ablaze with news of the treasures of this ancient civilization.
The new find is not, as some have suggested, the first royal tomb discovered in Egypt since Tutankhameâ€¦

entry.title: Painkillers donâ€™t work as well for women. Hereâ€™s why.
entry.summary:
Pain is one of the oldest complaints in medical history, and for millennia, treatments have been administered with a one-size-fits-all approach. It wasnâ€™t until recently that experts officially acknowledged one radical truth: Women experience pain differently than men, and by default, they donâ€™t respond to treatments as well.Â
Research shows that girls, women, and people assigned female at birth feel more severe pain than men, and are more likely to experience chronic conditions such as migraine, irritable bowel syndrome, fibromyalgia, and osteoarthritis. Yet, doctors are more likely to dismiss or ignore them, which leads to delays in treatment that exacerbate their pain.
At the same time, several studies show that over-the-counter and prescription painkillers like ibuprofen, steâ€¦

entry.title: Hunting for one of the rarest butterfliesâ€”named after her father
entry.summary:
My father once told me that the average lifespan of butterflies is seldom more than a few weeks.
Obsessed with them since he was a boy, he caught thousands during his lifetime. Using pins and tweezers, heâ€™d straighten their wings on a wooden spreader, not a single antenna damaged. Heâ€™d then affix the insects to a foam board by piercing tiny needles through their thorax and apply chemicals to preserve their bodies and wings. Heâ€™d meticulously arrange butterflies and moths according to their species and family in display cases. With the help of a magnifying lens, heâ€™d inscribe their Latin names on labels smaller than a sunflower seed. Encased in glass, his specimens glistened.
My father, Rustam Effendi, was a Soviet Azerbaijani lepidopterist, a preeminent authority on butterfliâ€¦

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals. Find related reports online at pewresearch.org/topic/economy-work. Kim Parker, Director of Social Trends ResearchJuliana Horowitz, Senior Associate Director, ResearchÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Luona Lin, Research AssociateRachel Minkin, Research AssociateÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Kiley Hurst, Research AnalystÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Dana Braga, Research AnalystReem Nadeem, Digital ProducerÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Peter Bell, Design DirectorJohn Carlo Mandapat, Information [â€¦] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Data in this report comes from Wave 157 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Centerâ€™s nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The survey was conducted Oct. 7-13, 2024, among a sample of ATP members who indicated that they currently work either full or part [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Workersâ€™ views of AI use in the workplace
entry.summary: To explore workersâ€™ views of AI use in the workplace, we asked about their broad attitudes on how AI may be used in the future and how it will affect their job opportunities in the long run. How workers feel about AI use in the workplace About half of workers (52%) say they feel worried [â€¦] The post 2. Workersâ€™ views of AI use in the workplace appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. Workersâ€™ experience with AI chatbots in their jobs
entry.summary: In addition to asking workers how they feel about and use AI in the workplace generally, we asked a series of questions specifically about workplace use of AI chatbots â€“ such as ChatGPT, Gemini or Copilot. A majority of workers (55%) rarely or never use AI chatbots at work. An additional 29% havenâ€™t heard of [â€¦] The post 3. Workersâ€™ experience with AI chatbots in their jobs appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. Workersâ€™ exposure to AI
entry.summary: Overall, most American workers (63%) say they donâ€™t use AI much or at all in their job. About one-in-six workers (16%) say at least some of their work is done with AI, including just 2% who say all or most of their work is done with AI. Some 17% of workers have not heard about [â€¦] The post 1. Workersâ€™ exposure to AI appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: U.S. Workers Are More Worried Than Hopeful About Future AI Use in the Workplace
entry.summary: American workers have mixed feelings about how AI technologies, like ChatGPT, will affect jobs in the future. The post U.S. Workers Are More Worried Than Hopeful About Future AI Use in the Workplace appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: â€˜Weâ€™re afraid to return homeâ€™: Uprooted again, Congolese civilians face hunger and more insecurity
entry.summary: Around 700,000 people were forced to leave Goma, one of the biggest cities in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) when it fell in January to rebels, known as M23. With the conflict spreading, many of them are on the move again but a return home is no guarantee of safety.

entry.summary: UN humanitarians reported on Tuesday that aid workers in Gaza supporting local health authorities have now managed to vaccinate nearly 550,000 children under 10 â€“ nearly all those it aimed to reach.

entry.title: Haiti: Gang violence displaces 6,000 people in one month
entry.summary: More than 6,000 people in Haiti have been forced from their homes by gang violence in almost a month, hampering aid efforts by humanitarian agencies, the United Nations warned on Tuesday.

entry.title: Itâ€™s possible to reverse diabetesâ€”and even faster than you think
entry.summary:
Diabetes is a debilitating, life-threatening chronic illness that puts people at greater risk of blindness, kidney failure, and heart disease. But weâ€™re also increasingly learning that itâ€™s not a condition a person needs to live with forever.Â
One in 10 people in the United States and more than 830 millionÂ people worldwide have the diseaseâ€”91 percent of them with type 2 diabetes; which, unlike type 1 diabetes, tends to develop in adulthood. About aÂ third of Americans also have prediabetesâ€”though more than 80 percent of themÂ don't know they have it.
"Type 2 diabetes is like having termites in your home in that it doesn't showÂ many symptoms at first, but can cause significant internal damage over time," says Osama Hamdy, senior staff physician at the Joslin Diabetes CenterÂ in Massaâ€¦

entry.title: Antoni Porowski wants you to learn your ancestorsâ€™ recipes
entry.summary: Chef Fabio Delledone shows Antoni Porowski and actor Justin Theroux how to make tortelli at Ristorante Belrespiro in Agazzano, Italy. As the host of No Taste Like Home, Porowski travels with celebrities to their ancestral homeland to explore their genealogy and the origins of their familyâ€™s culinary traditions. The Queer Eye star discusses his obsession with food, and helping others find their family history through food in the new travel series No Taste Like Home. Antoni Porowski believes in the importance of storytelling through culinary traditions. The child of Polish parents who immigrated to MontrÃ©al, he â€œfelt Polish enoughâ€ until the family moved to West Virginia and he began high school. Wanting to hang out with the cool kids, he noticed how he stood outâ€¦

entry.title: This is what a surgical clinic looked like in ancient Rome
entry.summary:
A mosaic of Orpheus ringed by animals paves the floor of what archaeologists believe was the consulting room of the early third-century A.D. Surgeonâ€™s House of Rimini, Italy. Discovered on accident in Rimini, Italy, this surgeonâ€™s house and the hooks, scalpels, and mortars inside have expanded what we knew about ancient medicine.
Workers were hardly surprised when they stumbled upon ancient ruins in the Italian town of Rimini in 1989. Now a popular tourist destination along the Adriatic coast, Riminiâ€”or Ariminum in ancient timesâ€”had been a major Roman town for centuries, and the modern city is strewn with monuments from that period.
What the workers found that spring day, however, would lead archaeologists to something quite unique: a cache of surgical instruments that had laiâ€¦

entry.title: Near perfect skull of apex predator reveals its 'meat cleaving bite'
entry.summary:
A species of the Hyaenodonta family as depicted by Heinrich Harder in Wilhelm Bolscheâ€™s Tiere der Urwelt (Animals of the Prehistoric World). A new fossil from this extinct predator gives scientists clues to how it lived and hunted. Some were the size of a dog. Others were as large as polar bears. A newly-discovered fossil of the ferocious hyaenodont is helping scientists understand a little bit more about the mysterious creatures.
Long before wolves or big cats, large hyaenodonts prowled the landscape.
Despite their name, the carnivores were not hyenas. Hyaenodonts were an ancient group of four-legged flesh-eaters that spread from ancient Europe through Africa, Asia, and North America between 56 and about 5 million years ago.
Most were small, comparable to a medium-sizedâ€¦

entry.title: These are the best adapters and converters for any device
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*Â
If youâ€™re planning to travel outside the United States, you need a reliable travel adapter and power converter. Differences in international power grids means there are no universal standards for voltage, frequency, or plug types around the world. Depending on where you go and which devices youâ€™re charging, you may need an adapter, a converter, or both.Â
A travel adapter simply lets you plug into different outlets. A converter adjusts the voltage sâ€¦

entry.title: Winter brings more indoor air pollution
entry.summary:
Most of us associate air pollution with the outdoorsâ€”from car or bus exhaust in a city to industrial waste or wildfire smoke. But you may not realize the air inside your home can be even more contaminated, especially in winter. Since home is where we spend some 70 percent of our timeâ€”more if youâ€™re one of the 35 percent of workers who do some or all business from thereâ€”these toxins can have an outsized impact on your health.
Outdoor pollutants are regulated by the Clean Air Act, but no comparable federal law governs what lurks inside your dwelling. Yet exposure to common winter indoor toxins can cause myriad health conditions, including respiratory and cardiovascular diseases, chronic inflammation, and cancer. Some research has even linked them to premature death, says Nicholas Nassikâ€¦

entry.title: Try this destination for cherry blossoms instead of Japan
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The end of South Koreaâ€™s long, frigid winter is announced by puffs of pink and white. Cherry blossom season is a big deal here, celebrated with local festivals and flower-themed drinks â€” and itâ€™s as beautiful as it is fleeting. Southern Jeju island sees its first blossom in mid-March, while up in the mountains of the northern mainland, buds can linger on until the end of April. The blooms usually peak a week or so after first appearing, and soon after lie in pale mounds on the ground.
Itâ€™s difficult to avoid comparisons with neighbouring Japan, over the sea. There, cherry blossom-viewing â€” an experience known locally as hanami â€” is more well-established. But South Korea is the more affordable of the two countries, â€¦

entry.title: 8 of the most scenic train journeys in the UK
entry.summary:
The North Yorkshire Moors Railway was first launched in the 1830s. UK rail is once again in the spotlight as the country marks the 200<sup>th</sup> anniversary of the worldâ€™s first public railway this year. Pay tribute to those early pioneers by riding the UKâ€™s most scenic rails.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Mainland Europe has been basking in a not-so-quiet rail revolution for the past few years, but now the spotlight is firmly on the UK. 2025 marks 200 years since the opening of the Stockton and Darlington Railway â€” the worldâ€™s first public railway â€” and the much-anticipated Britannic Explorer, A Belmond Train arrives in July. As train travel across the UK takes off once more, here are eight train journeys with views you wonâ€™t want to miâ€¦

entry.title: How to explore Oman's green peaks
entry.summary: High inÂ theÂ rocky mountains of Omanâ€™s interior,Â theÂ desertÂ blooms, beckoning travellers to experience a corner of the country that's resplendent in its rural beauty. Jabal Akhdar is around two hours' drive from Muscat and enjoys a mild microclimate thanks to an inland position and high altitude. As a result, it's home to flourishing landscapes, with fruit and rose orchards smothering slopes in fragrant and colourful blossoms. Visitors can easily immerse themselves in its spectacularly rugged landscapes on foot, with the milder weather providing ample opportunities for exploration of its villages and hiking routes. Witness the plunging depths of nearby Wadi Ghul â€” nicknamed â€˜the Grand Canyon of Arabiaâ€™, while ancient settlements carved into Jabal Akhdar's precipices add a surreal beauty to â€¦

entry.title: Where to eat and drink in Copenhagen
entry.summary: With 26 Michelin stars found across its historic streets, Copenhagen is undeniably a culinary powerhouse. The city is home to some of the worldâ€™s most innovative restaurants â€” including Alchemist, a theatrical dining experience headed by Rasmus Munk, the reigning Worldâ€™s Best Chef â€” yet, thereâ€™s no need to break the bank on a visit here. There are plenty of affordable restaurants showcasing traditional Danish cuisine, as well as first-rate bakeries, where youâ€™ll find delights like the â€˜Vienneseâ€™ (a pastry named after the city in which its Danish creator found inspiration). On a winter visit, join the locals on a quest to find the cityâ€™s best fastelavnsboller â€” seasonal cakes that liven up bakery windows from January onwards. From street-side food vendors to rustic waterfront breweries, thiâ€¦

entry.title: Greenland: life at the edge of the world
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The Inuit of Greenland have 80 different words for ice. Niels Davidsen is currently most familiar with sikuuvoq (sea covered by a layer of ice) because the sikuuvoq has stolen his boat. It is currently sikkuppaa (frozen into sea ice) in the harbour of Ilulissat, on the west coast of Greenland, and there it will stay for a couple more months. Come June, the thaw will rescue the vessel and its many neighbours, or else the town will decide its winter visitor has outstayed its welcome and employ an ice-breaker or dynamite to swiftly blast an ammavoq (passage in sea ice for a boat to pass through) and be done with it.
For now, though, Niels visits his little white boat in Illulissat harbour every so often to chip off thâ€¦

entry.title: This asteroid might not hit Earth in 2032 after all
entry.summary:
Asteroids fly by Earth on a regular basis, and most of them are of no concern whatsoever. But sometimes a space rock gets flagged as a potential threat because there is a slim chance that it may collide with Earth. A newly discovered near-Earth asteroid called 2024 YR4 is one possibly perilous object: Itâ€™s a 130 to 300-foot long rock that could impact somewhere on Earth on December 22, 2032.
To be clear, there is no need to hurriedly invest in a hardened bunker. This asteroid is certainly worth watching because it could devastate a city with a direct hitâ€”even on the small side of its size estimate. At one point, the rock had a 3.1 percent chance of a violent rendezvous with Earthâ€”the highest ever recorded. The odds have since fallen to 1.5 percent and will most likely, drop precipitouâ€¦

entry.title: In Catalonia, try this self-sufficient fine-dining restaurant
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
In the hills to the west of Barcelona, Casa Nova is a temple to the art of slow, soulful cooking. Itâ€™s the kind of place that, using only what is naturally abundant, relies on age-old methods and the particularities of a regionâ€™s terrain, climate and cultures.
In fact, the restaurant, a farmhouse in the fertile PenedÃ¨s countryside famed for its white wines, claims to be 98% self-sufficient, with the remainder sourced from local producers. There are just seven staff who grow, cook, deliver and then explain all the food â€” no waiters â€” and a dining room with only six tables, Casa Nova offers an experience akin to visiting a friendâ€™s farm â€” if that friend happened to be one of the world's most innovative chefs.
Anâ€¦

entry.title: Go on a luxury rail journey through Peruvian mountains
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Holding aloft pairs of dry coca leaves, the dancers pause, drums beating faster, before they burst into song. Over shouts of â€œHeh! Heh! Heh!â€, they play melodies on a quena (an Andean flute) while passengers gather around, squinting through the smoke from offerings burning on the platform at Poroy Station. Coloured with vegetable dyes, the welcome troupeâ€™s skirts flare as they hop from one foot to the other, setting the tone for the next four hours: a journey filled with music, colour and Indigenous Quechua culture.
Iâ€™m here to ride the luxury Hiram Bingham, run by Belmond Trains, from the district of Cusco in southeastern Peru to the town of Aguas Calientes in the foothills of the ancient Inca citadel of Machu Picâ€¦

entry.title: Amtrak's Gulf Coast train line is backâ€”hereâ€™s whatâ€™s to expect
entry.summary:
En route to Biloxi from New Orleans, the train passes Gulfport Beach in Mississippi. Amtrakâ€™s southern route prepares to reopen, following a 20-year hiatus after Hurricane Katrina.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Linking the Mardi Gras capital of New Orleans in Louisiana and the waterfront city of Mobile in Alabama, Amtrakâ€™s Gulf Coast train is set to become one of the USAâ€™s great rail routes once more when it relaunches in spring 2025. Following the southern US shoreline for most of its three-hour journey, it passes through Louisianaâ€™s Cajun country â€” known for its miles of bayous, traditional festivals and hearty gumbos (spicy Cajun chicken soup) â€” and coastal Mississippi. The latter is a lesser-visited area with white-sand beaches, fresh câ€¦

entry.title: Ukraine war: Amid shifting alliances, General Assembly passes resolution condemning Russiaâ€™s aggression
entry.summary: Three years to the day since Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine, the UN General Assembly adopted two competing resolutions on resolving the conflict on Monday, one initiated by the United States and the other by Ukraine â€“ a sign of strategic differences within the transatlantic alliance over the way forward for peace.

entry.title: World News in Brief: Famine in Sudan, Gaza polio campaign continues, West Bank update, Kenyan officer killed in Haiti
entry.summary: Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres expressed deep concern on Monday following the announcement by Sudanâ€™s Rapid Support Forces (RSF) militia and affiliated groups, of a political charter proposing the establishment of a rival governing authority in RSF-controlled areas to the transitional Government.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Eastern DR Congo: Crisis deepens as crime and insecurity surges
entry.summary: The humanitarian crisis in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) is worsening as M23 rebel attacks continue to drive tens of thousands from their homes and claim hundreds of lives, UN humanitarians warned on Monday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Nuclear weapons are â€˜one-way road to annihilationâ€™ warns Guterres
entry.summary: UN Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres on Monday warned that the risk of nuclear conflict is rising â€“ as global security arrangements unravel and military spending soars â€“ urging governments to push for total disarmament.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Breast cancer cases projected to rise by nearly 40 per cent by 2050, WHO warns
entry.summary: Breast cancer cases are expected to increase by 38 percent globally by 2050, with annual deaths from the disease projected to rise by 68 percent, according to a new report from the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), a specialised branch of the World Health Organization (WHO).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UKRAINE LIVE: Diplomatic debate intensifies as world marks three years since full-scale Russian invasion
entry.summary: February 24 marks three years since Russia launched a full-scale invasion of Ukraine. Thousands of civilians have been killed and injured, the economy shattered and energy infrastructure destroyed. As the General Assembly and Security Council debated how peace and security can be restored in eastern Europe, three resolutions were passed which reveal new policies and alliances that signal a major shift in the pattern of diplomacy towards the war, here in New York. UN News app users can follow live here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Worldâ€™s â€˜warmongersâ€™ must end disdain for global order, UN chief insists
entry.summary: With no end to numerous protracted conflicts - not least in Ukraine, three years to the day since the full-scale Russian invasion - UN chief AntÃ³nio Guterres on Monday scorned the worldâ€™s â€œwarmongersâ€ for trampling on peopleâ€™s most fundamental rights.

entry.title: Using WhatsApp to Crowdsource Data on Ride Hailing Companiesâ€™ Labor Lockouts
entry.summary: Bloomberg investigative data journalist Leon Yin used WhatsApp to crowdsource data from Uber and Lyft drivers in New York City about company lockouts during a local, minimum wage dispute.

entry.title: GIJN Webinar: The Future of Funding Investigative Journalism: Strategies & Challenges
entry.summary: In this GIJN webinar, attendees will learn how to diversify revenue streams, approach funders while safeguarding editorial independence, and adapt to the evolving funding landscape. The panel brings together three top experts with deep experience in media fundraising, business strategy, and philanthropic support for journalism, ready to share their knowledge and real-world strategies.
